description: The hospital displays information to patients and families on services provided

subStandards.description: The hospital uses a variety of methods to display information, such as posters, brochures, media, MOH portals, or websites, with methods of how to access its services.
All hospital staff are oriented to these services, mainly the staff in reception, outpatient department, and in-patient departments.
The hospital uses appropriate language and format to provide information about its services to patients, families, and community.

description: The hospital implements a mechanism to ensure the provision of a unified standard of care to patients.

subStandards.description: Patient’s care is provided according to the policies, laws and regulations.

Department leaders ensure that all patients receive the same standards of care throughout the hospital departments, all the time (during the morning, afternoon, or night, working hours, or off-hours, regardless of their race, gender, or religion and whether they can pay or not.
Every patient has an individualized care plan based on their initial assessment and reassessment.
Each patient attending in-patient or outpatient services receives awareness about their rights and responsibilities.
The hospital designs and carries out processes to provide continuity of patient care services in the hospital and coordination among health care providers.
The hospital has qualified professionals responsible for the patient’s care during all phases of in-patient care.

description: The hospital has a standardized method for registration and admission of patients within its scope of services that meet patients' health needs.

subStandards.description: The hospital has clear policy and procedures describing the process used for admission in various departments, including but not limited to:
All staff are oriented about the standardized process of admission of patients to various hospital settings.
Each patient has a unique registration identification number through the process of admission.
Patients are accepted only if the hospital can provide the services.
Hospital department leaders conduct monitoring audits to assess staff compliance to policies and procedures.
The staff are oriented to the admission policy and procedure to ensure a consistent admission process in the hospital units/ department.
Each department has an admission criterion designed for their scope of service.
There is regular audit conducted to monitor compliance admission process by healthcare staff to ensure standardized practice.

description: The hospital has clear mechanism for patients transfer.

subStandards.description: The hospital has a documented transfer policy of patients’ intra and inter hospital.
The Hospital staff are oriented about the transfer process.

The hospital leaders and staff are responsible to provide detailed information on patient medical and nursing assessments, the reason for the transfer, clinical findings, medication use, and all related information.
There is a unified checklist is recommended to structure the transfer process and mitigate risks to the patients.
The staff responsible to receive the patient in the receiving unit is responsible to assess the patient’s condition on arrival, to ensure patient safety and transfer to appropriate service.
The hospital monitors the compliance of the healthcare staff with the transfer policy to ensure standardized practice.

description: The hospital has a clear process for assessment of patients throughout care process.

subStandards.description: Hospital has clear policies and procedures for patients’ physical  assessment and re-assessment, time frame for completion of the initial assessment process and the frequency of reassessment, content of assessment in different care setting such as:
The policy and procedures define the scope and content of assessment by each discipline such as physicians, nurses, social services and dietitians, and other service providers.
The hospital ensures training is conducted for the concerned staff to follow policies and procedures of proper assessment.
The assessment includes discharge planning, the type of diagnostic testing required, and priorities of the level of care required.

The is evidence to ensure all patients are reassessed at appropriate intervals as per the policy, to determine response to treatment, detect complications or adverse reactions, compliance to treatment, to plan the further continuation of treatment or change accordingly.
The hospital uses standardized assessments tools:
Patients are being reassessed to confirm effectiveness of care plans, patient response to treatment, patient compliance with treatment, plan continuation of treatment etc.
Documentation of patient’s care plan is maintained in electronic medical records.
Each department head conducts regular monitoring to ensure staff compliance to their concerned policy and procedures.

description: The hospital uses evidence-based clinical practice guidelines to guide care for patients as applicable, in various clinical specialties.

subStandards.description: The Hospital has clinical practice guidelines, protocols, pathways that are developed as per evidence- based medicine.
These guidelines are used to guide healthcare providers in making appropriate clinical decisions.
These guidelines are updated every 2-3 years or earlier as required.
The department monitors compliance with guidelines to ensure the staff are following the clinical practice guidelines.

description: The hospital has a process to identify and deal with patients requiring urgent or emergent care.

subStandards.description: Hospital has clear written guidelines/ pathways to identify and manage patients who are on need for urgent or emergent care.   This includes  but not limited to:
Staff are trained on process of determining the severity of patient’s condition and handling patients as per the written guidelines.
The hospital ensures appropriate timely care is provided for emergent cases.
There is always regular process of monitoring the process to ensure proper implantation and follow up.

description: The hospital has a process to obtain informed consent before any procedure requiring informed consent.

subStandards.description: The hospital has a policy for obtaining informed consent from a patient or his/ her legal representative before starting invasive or high-risk procedures or treatment. The policy includes explanations of the nature of the procedures/ treatment, benefits, or expected harms.
The hospital identifies the list of procedures require informed consent, including, but are not limited to:
The Hospital has evidence of training records for staff on the informed consent policy.
The informed consent is available and easily accessible to all staff.
Informed consent can only be obtained by the physician conducting the procedure or/and surgery.
There is evidence that if a patient is unable to give informed consent (e.g., minors or mentally incompetent patients), consent should is filled by patient’s next of kin or guardian.
The Hospital has a regular process to measuring the compliance to the policy.

description: The hospital has a process to meet the needs of terminally ill patients and end of life care

subStandards.description: The hospital has clear guide on providing effective care for terminally ill patients such as pain management and other symptoms.
The Hospital staff are well oriented on the end-of-life care guide.
The hospital staff assesses and attend patients’ specific needs such as pain management, feeding, skin care, turning, etc.
The hospital staff responds to the individual needs of terminally ill patients, such as physical, psychological, spiritual, and cultural needs.
The hospital staff educates and involves family members on the care decision.
The team follows right process to transfer patient to another hospital if hospital is unable to provide palliative care service to a patient.
There is regular monitoring audit to assess staff compliance to the guide and to assess the effectiveness of the implemented process.
The Hospital has clear policies to guide on identifying and assessing patients vulnerable to harm self, or others including patients with psychiatric issues such as:
The Hospital staff are oriented to these policies.
Referral is made to the hospital providing specific management in case of unavailability of the services required.
If patients are for transfer, patients and family are informed.
There is regular audit performed to assess compliance to these policies.

description: The hospital has a process to coordinate patient care among healthcare teams.

subStandards.description: The Hospital has a system to facilitate the continuity of a coordinated provision of care to patients.

The system includes patient’s medical records that allow sharing information of patients’ care and treatment between authorized multidisciplinary team, including medical, nursing, and all other health care providers.
Department leaders ensure that there is complete documentation of care progression of patients and length of stay, effectiveness, and evidence for improvement.
The Hospital has clear policy and procedures of pain management, which clearly defines the need for comprehensive pain assessment, reassessment, and management.
The hospital considers patient pain management as basic patient right.
The policy includes process of assessing pain intensity, frequency, location, duration, and type.
The Hospital’s staff are trained on their role in pain assessment, reassessment, and management.
There is evidence of pain assessment based on validated pain assessment scale
The staff conducts pain assessment, and document it frequently as planned for patients, including pain history (site, radiation, intensity, character etc.)
The pain scoring  is done before giving pain medication, and at regular intervals post dosing (e.g., Pain scale-numeric rating system, Wong-Baker FACES pain rating scale).
Planning for pain management is done prior to surgery or any painful intervention/procedure.
The pain management is based on patient’s condition, using different pharmacologic and non-therapeutic methods.
Department leaders conduct regular audits to assess staff compliance to the policy.
The Hospital has a documented discharge planning policy/guide
The Hospital ensures the staff are aware about the discharge planning policy.
The patient discharge planning starts as early time as the admission time.
Patients and the family are involved in the discharge process.

The process includes at least one meeting between the patient, family, and discharge planner to help the patient to be prepared for discharge. The meeting addresses patients' needs after discharge to prevent possible risks at home
The staff coordinate with other health care institutions as appropriate to patients’ needs. Patients and their family are involved in this decision.
There is a discharge summery prepared for all inpatients before they leave the hospital, with clear documentation
Department leaders conduct regular audit to assess compliance with the policy.

description: Hospital identifies and manages patients at risk of developing venous thromboembolism (VTE). (CSS 7)

subStandards.description: Hospital has an updated written thrombo prophylaxis guideline or policy to screen patients for the risk of developing VTE.
The guidelines are periodically updated as per evidence-based practice
The guidelines are made available and easily accessible in all departments and staff are well oriented to the guidelines.
The treating team follows the guideline to identify patients at risk to develop DVT, pulmonary embolism (PE), and implement applicable prophylaxis.
The hospital implements measures to regularly audit implementations of appropriate thromboprophylaxis to ensure all at-risk patients, are identified and managed according to the current guidelines.
The concerned healthcare worker provides health education to patients about the risk of VTE  medication use measures to prevent it, and any relevant and needed information.
The guidelines are made available and easily accessible in all departments and staff are well oriented to the guidelines.

description: The hospital implements a standardized process of patient identifiaction through out the hospital.(CSS.3)

subStandards.description: The hospital has a clear standardized policy of patient identification that covers main identifiers (full name, date of birth, unique hospital identification number), ID wrist band, patient photo identification.
All hospital staff oriented on the policy and its procedures.
Patient’s identification used before performing any procedure.
Hospital staff actively involves patient in the confirmation process.
The hospital conducts regular audit to ensure compliance to the policy.

description: The hospital implements an effective process for timely reporting of urgent critical diagnostic results.

subStandards.description: The hospital implements a policy for reporting abnormal critical diagnostic test results
The hospital describes the critical values for each diagnostic test.

The hospital implements a standardized process to ensure immediate and accurate critical results reporting and receiving , describing precisely the first liners (the reporter and the receiver ) of the critical results and alternatives in case first liners are not available , aiming to immediate care management to given to the patients .
All concerned staff are oriented on the policy.
The hospital monitors the implementation of reporting process, ensuring information are documented in patients’ medical records.

description: The hospital has laboratory services that are applicable to national laws and regulations, to meet patient needs.

subStandards.description: The hospital has laboratory services that are under national standards, laws, and regulations.

The laboratory services unit has a clear scope of services to meet the needs related to the hospital mission and patient populations, emergency needs, covering twenty- four hours a day, seven days a week.
Essential, simple laboratory services are available twenty- four hours a day, seven days a week. This includes hematology services, biochemistry, and blood bank).
When special diagnostic tests are not available, there is clear process for referral and follow up of diagnostic tests.

description: The laboratory has qualified, competent staff to provide the defined scope of services.

subStandards.description: The director/head of the laboratory services is qualified by education, training and experience in the field

All laboratory staff are appropriately qualified (by education and training), and experienced to manage and perform tests and interpret results, according to the complexity of laboratory scope of services.
Laboratory has clear job description for each staff category
Staff with experience in the area manage different laboratory sections.
New laboratory personnel receive an orientation to the hospital and laboratory services.
All laboratory staff have the required education, training, qualifications, and experience to administer and perform the tests and interpret the results.
Laboratory uses appropriate competency assessment tools to assess staff performance.

description: The laboratory has an established comprehensive quality management system (QMS).

subStandards.description: The laboratory management has an established, documented, implemented and monitored quality management system manual.
The laboratory management has assigned a quality manger or a quality focal point with clear responsibilities and roles.
The quality management system is fulfilling the integration of all processes, policies, and objectives in the testing cycle and meets the needs of the users.
Laboratory quality indicators are established and monitored.
All laboratory staff are oriented about the quality management system in the lab.
There is periodic audit conducted to assess compliance to policies related to quality management in the lab.
Non-conformance management system is followed with corrective action plan.

description: The laboratory has an implemented, health safety program.

subStandards.description: The laboratory has an approved health and safety program, and infection control policies and procedures manuals that comply with the national laws and regulations. This includes but is not limited to:
The laboratory has a health and safety officer with clear job roles and responsibilities.
The laboratory has a risk management plan which addresses potential safety risks in the lab and other areas outside the laboratory where laboratory services are provided
The laboratory has a safety and security training plan, documented.
The laboratory has an internal and external disaster plan.
The laboratory dress code policy is implemented and monitored
An updated detailed inventory of all hazardous material is available.
Staff has received necessary vaccinations as per the requirement of performed tasks.
Infectious and hazardous waste are handled, treated and disposed appropriately.
All incident and injuries are addressed according to the protocols.
There is regular audit plan to access compliance to the safety program guidelines.

description: The laboratory has a suitable adequate workspace, services, to maintain a safe and appropriate working environment.

subStandards.description: The laboratory has standard working environment guidelines.
Hospital ensures there is adequate space allocated for the laboratory, that provides:
Hospital laboratory management ensures the availability of
Hospital laboratory management ensures that access to laboratory areas is controlled
The laboratory controls, regularly audits and monitors the environmental conditions.
The laboratory has a clear  procedure in the event of power failure

description: The laboratory has a defined system for supply and management of reagents and consumables.
The laboratory has assigned authorized personnel with defined job responsibilities for reagents and consumables.

subStandards.description: The laboratory has implemented policies and procedures for the appropriate management and storage of reagents and consumables, according to the manufacturer’s recommendations under controlled settings.
The laboratory management ensures that reagents and their consumables are monitored using an appropriate, standardized temperature monitoring system.
The laboratory has an evaluation protocol for new reagents.
The laboratory has an inventory system for reagents and consumables.
The laboratory has procedures available for Malfunction/manufacturing defects of reagents and consumables.
Safety Data Sheets are available for all applicable reagents.
Laboratory has an implemented audit system to ensure safety and functions of the reagents

description: The laboratory has a system for introducing, validating, and the management of equipment.

subStandards.description: Laboratory has a copy of all equipment maintenance contracts.
Laboratory has an equipment’s S.O.P
There are clear procedures for the calibration of equipment with traceable certificates of calibrators.
Laboratory has a procedure for the verification of equipment performance.
Equipment is operated and maintained by trained and competent personnel.
Equipment Log books are maintained.
Laboratory management conducts regular audit to ensure compliance to policies and procedures to ensure safe equipment management.

description: The hospital an established laboratory quality assurance program.

subStandards.description: The laboratory implements policies and procedures on quality performance indicators and systems checks.
The laboratory internal quality assurance program is established
The internal quality control results are reviewed and analyzed regularly with needed corrective action plans.
The laboratory external quality assurance program is available
The program addresses surveillance of test results.
The Laboratory has a documented procedure to identify, manage and control nonconformance.
The program includes the documentation of corrective and preventive actions.
All laboratory staff are well oriented on laboratory quality assurance program.
There is constant audit to assess compliance to the QA program implementation

description: Laboratory implements a total Testing Processes (TTP) system

subStandards.description: Laboratory has an updated user manual, reception and rejection standard operation procedures S.O.P.

The laboratory has a standard operation procedure (SOP) that clearly explains the pre-examination, examination and post examination process (e.g., Examination, reporting, storage, retention and disposal of clinical samples) with authorized responsibilities including routine, urgent, and referral samples.
The laboratory ensures the selection of approved and validated examination procedure before introducing the test into service.
The internal and the external quality control systems are implemented, interpreted, data analyzed and corrective action performed and maintained.
The laboratory defines the biological reference intervals and /or clinical decision limits.
All staff laboratory staff are oriented and a ware about the SOP.
The lab has a defined system for reporting method with an effective communication with the end-users by authorized person with a clear and accurate reporting format.
There are clear procedures for the amendment of results.
Laboratory monitors key quality indicators covering the pre-examination, examination and post examination process phases of the laboratory operations.

description: Hospital has a comprehensive system for effective management and use of point of care testing (PoCT ).

subStandards.description: The laboratory implements  PoCT policies and procedures, which describe responsibilities of managing the  PoCT to the lab, process of  PoCT, training requirement, quality control testing of  PoCT methods.
Laboratory has PoCT committee members with rules and regulations and terms of references.
There are clear guidelines describing the process of PoCT .
The staff are trained and assessed for competency for testing
The laboratory has assigned personnel as PoCT coordinator.
There is regular audit to ensure, quality control testing is performed and recorded for PoCT .
Patients’ results are interpreted by trained personnel, and all abnormal results are confirmed by the laboratory if recommended

description: The laboratory has a defined information and data management system.

subStandards.description: Laboratory has a defined system (manual/electronic) to identify and relate information to patients
Laboratory has a procedure for information and data management.
Laboratory information are protected from/against unauthorized access, tempering and loss.
Laboratory has a contingency plan system failure/breakdown
Laboratory has a system for sample tracking and data traceability.
Laboratory ensures training of all staff in using data management system

description: The radiology department is well staffed with qualified, trained, experienced staff.

subStandards.description: The director/ head of radiology department is qualified, trained, skilled and experienced radiologist.
The radiology department staff have proper qualifications, training, and experience.
Hospital has twenty-four-hour radiology service coverage
The radiology department has a mechanism on developing human resources.
The radiology department have records of staff trained in Basic Life Support (BLS).

description: The hospital radiology imaging services are provided as per the scope of the hospital, and National laws and regulations.

subStandards.description: Radiology department services comply with legal and other requirements.
Scope of the imaging services is commensurate to the services provided by the hospital.
The infrastructure (physical and equipment) and manpower is adequate to provide for its defined scope of services.
Adequately qualified and trained personnel perform, supervise and interpret the investigations.
Documented and updated policies and procedures exist to ensure correct identification and safe and timely transportation of patients to and from the imaging services.
The results are available within a defined timeframe
Critical results are intimated immediately to the personnel concerned
The results are reported in a standardized manner.
There is a mechanism to address recall / amendment of reports whenever applicable.
Imaging tests that are not available in the hospital are outsourced to other hospital(s) based on their quality assurance system

description: The radiology department has policy and procedures manual to guide all radiological procedures.

subStandards.description: Hospital radiology department has policy and procedures address all important radiological investigations and procedures, including but is not limited to:  X-ray, ultrasounds, computed tomography (CT) scan, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), angiogram, nuclear medicine imaging, portable radiology machines, mammography, etc.
All radiology staff are trained and oriented to policies and procedures in their concerned areas.
Department leaders conduct audit to assess compliance to policies and procedures safety measures in a regular predefined interval.

description: The radiology department has a quality assurance program for radiology and diagnostic imaging services.

subStandards.description: Hospital implements a quality assurance program for radiology and diagnostic testing.
The program addresses periodic internal/external peer reviews of imaging protocols and results using appropriate sampling.
The program addresses surveillance of imaging results in collaboration with referring clinicians for follow up wherever applicable.
A system is in place to ensure the appropriateness of the investigations and procedures for the clinical indications.
The program includes periodic calibration and maintenance of all equipment.
The program includes the documentation of corrective and preventive actions.
The program includes daily surveillance and documentation of imaging results.
The program includes regular audit process for correction and improvement.

description: The radiology department has an established documented safety program in the diagnostic imaging services. (CSS 11)

subStandards.description: The department has documented radiation-safety program, which aligns with the hospital’s safety program.
The program includes the management (Handling, usage and disposal, storing and transportation) of radioactive materials and hazardous materials used for therapeutic and diagnostic purposes.
The program includes checking/screening patients for safety risks before exposure to any imaging procedures, e.g., checking female patients for pregnancy.
The program includes guidelines and procedures that governs the use of  contrast media.
The program includes guidelines and procedures for non- radiation hazards. E.g., infection control, electrical hazards and immobilization.
The program guides monitoring of the staff for radiation exposure, periodically.
Imaging signage is prominently displayed in all appropriate locations.
The program includes regular testing of radiation protecting aprons, thyroid, and gonad shield for patients and staff.
The department’s leaders maintain records on staff radiation exposure for the last year.
The program includes regular testing of radiation protecting aprons, thyroid, and gonad shield for patients and staff
The program includes regular testing of radiation protecting aprons, thyroid, and gonad shield for patients and staff
Radiology department leaders maintain records on staff radiation exposure for the last year.
Radiology department leaders ensure that all staff are aware about the safety program.
There is a regular audit to monitor the implementation of the safety program.

description: The Emergency Department has documented scope of services.

subStandards.description: The Emergency Department has clearly written scope of service.
The emergency staff are well oriented to the scope of service
Emergency care is provided to all patients seeking treatment at the ED regardless of their gender, religion, nationality or socioeconomic status.

description: Emergency Department is well equipped with qualified medical and nursing staff.

subStandards.description: Emergency Department is directed by a physician who is qualified by education, training, and experience in managing emergency patients.
The Emergency Department is covered by registered physicians, who are qualified to manage emergency cases, twenty-four hours a day seven days a week.
Emergency Department nurse manager is qualified by education, training and experience in emergency.
Emergency Department staff receive training, and education as per relevant scope of services.
Emergency Department medical and nursing staff are certified in BLS, ACLS.
There is documented ongoing competency assessment for all medical and nursing team in the department.

description: The emergency department is well established and easily accessible to receive and manage emergency patients

subStandards.description: The Emergency Department is identified through clear signage from outside and inside the hospital.
The emergency department has separate identified entrance (s).
ED entrance is controlled and only limited for clinical staff;  and not allowed for the by non-clinical staff and off-hours visitors.
The ED triage area is directly visible and accessible from the department entrance
The ED triage area is properly equipped with:
The ED triage area has easy access to 12 leads ECG
The ED triage room has a glass window or alternatives (e.g., CCTV) that allows visual access of patients in the waiting room.
The triage area maintains patient privacy
There is an existing or provisional area to be utilized as a secondary triage post to support the main triage area when needed
There is a utilization plan that describes when to operate the additional triage.
The waiting area allows maximum comfort by providing

description: Emergency department has documented policies, procedures, pathways, and guidelines, and applicable laws and regulations to guide the care of patients.

subStandards.description: ED has clearly documented policies and procedures that are consistent with the hospital and emergency department scope of services.
The ED policies, procedures, and guidelines are prepared by the emergency department multidisciplinary team including the ED head, nurse leader.
The policies address the handling of medico-legal cases, such as cases such as alcohol and narcotic abuse and criminal acts.
The policies address the management of suspected victims of abuse, neglect, and domestic violence.
The policies address the management of poisoning, multi-trauma, acute coronary syndrome, VTE, stroke, sepsis, acute pain, etc.
The policies guide the triage of patients.
The ED documented policies and procedures guide the management of patients found dead on arrival at the hospital.
ED staff are all familiar and trained with policies and procedures.
The department/ unit conducts a regular audit to assess compliance and well implantation of the guidelines and policies.

description: The ED has effective ambulance services.

subStandards.description: ED has adequate access and space for the ambulance(s).
ED has full supervision and responsibility for the ambulance services.
The ambulance adheres to the national rules and regulations
The ambulance is operated by trained personnel in BLS.
The ED has a clear written protocol for communication between ambulance and the hospital, for receiving or transferring patients.
The ambulance is fully equipped and has enough supply, to be ready for transfer of patients all the time.
Ambulance is equipped with basic life support equipment for both adult and pediatric patients, and medications.
Ambulance equipment and medications are checked on a daily basis using standardized checklist.
Ambulances maintenance is conducted on regular predefined schedule, and documented.

Emergency department leader ensures there is adherence to infection control policy, in running vehicle and maintaining equipment cleaning, ensuring there is a regular schedule for cleaning with assigned personnel.
The ED is equipped with all necessary equipment, resources and medications suitable to types of services provided.
The ED resuscitation room that is easily accessible from the ED entrance and physically located in close proximity to OT, ICU and radiology
Resuscitation/trauma rooms have sufficient space to perform resuscitation
The ED has treatment area assigned for high acuity patients.
The ED has a treatment area assigned for low acuity patients.
The ED has a treatment area assigned for pediatric patients.
The ED has a treatment area assigned for GYN assessment.

The resuscitation trolley is located in the center of the resuscitation area and has even spaces around it and the surrounding space that ensures 360° access to all parts of the patient for procedures.
There is specialized equipment necessary for management of ophthalmology, ENT, and dental emergency cases.
ED has specific facility to ensure patient privacy and safety are maintained in all locations.
All bed locations have direct access and easily observed by ED staff.
ED has regular process of checking supply stock and equipment.

description: Emergency department implements standardized effective triage system to prioritize patients.

subStandards.description: The ED has a clear written guide on triage system to categorize patients and identify those with emergent care needs.
ED has a structured training program to ensure all staff are aware about the system
ED staff ensure patients with urgent needs are provided with appropriate care on timely manner.
There is a  regular quality audit system to  monitor the right implementation of triaging system, such as under triage and over triage are promptly addressed and corrected.

description: Emergency department laboratory and imaging tests are completed and results are communicated on a timely manner.

subStandards.description: ED has laboratory and radiology diagnostic services available all days and times.
Laboratory and diagnostic imaging results are available to the ED staff within identified timeframe.
There is regular scheduled audit to ensure investigation results are communicated on time to ensure appropriate, timely patient management.
There is a clear written guide for the Redirection process
Staff are educated on patient Redirection
Redirection is done for low acuity patients (triage levels 4 and 5 only)
There is a process to regularly review patient redirection

description: ED has written scheduling guide for emergency physicians and nurses.

subStandards.description: ED has duty roster for clinical staff (doctors and nurses), as per the institution policy for each team, covering number of hours, number of shifts, on-call, annual leave plan, training activities schedule, approved by head of department.
There are clockwise shift rotation patterns (mornings, afternoons, nights).
The staff schedule is easily accessible to all ED staff
There is a minimum of 10 hours between finishing and resuming clinical duties.
Leadership conducts regular random audit to assess compliance with the duty roster guidelines.
There are regular 48-hour minimum periods off work with no less than a total of 60 hours per fortnight.
On-call is limited to no more than two overnight on-calls per seven days with neither being consecutive.
There is a proper skill mix staffing for each shift as per ED needs.
There is provision for adequate annual leave, conference leave and professional development leave.
There is a regular predefined schedule to monitor the compliance to the policy.

description: The hospital has a Clinical Pharmacist available to attend the ED during each shift.

subStandards.description: The hospital has a qualified (by education, and experience) clinical pharmacist to cover the ED.
The clinical pharmacist is available to respond to calls from the ED during peak volume hours, 24 hours a day.
The clinical pharmacist has a clear job description in the ED
The clinical pharmacist is part of a multidisciplinary team.
The ED has a set of key quality indicators to monitor and report on regular basis, including but is not limited to: ER Triage to physician time, average length of stay of patients, etc.
These quality indicators are well known by all ED staff.
ED conducts audit to assess performance on a regular predetermined interval, and set plan of actions accordingly.

description: The Nursing department maintains a current scope of practice for the Nursing department.

subStandards.description: There is a written scope of practice for each nursing specialty that is approved and signed by the director/ head of nursing and directorate of nursing Affairs.
Each nursing specialty desired education, skills, knowledge and other requirement is defined in the scope of practice document.
Each unit has a head nurse/nurse manager with the required nursing and managerial experience, and a clear scope of practice
Each staff nurse’s specific responsibilities are defined in the current scope of practice.
All nurses are aware about their scope of practice.
Nursing staff are allocated according to skill level and appropriate qualifications and specialties.
Nurse leaders conduct periodic review to ensure that nursing services are provided by registered nurses in accordance with their license and scope of practice.

description: The nursing department has essential policies and procedures available, to guide the nursing practice.

subStandards.description: The nursing department has documented policies and procedures manuals for all activities of the nursing services that are approved and signed by nursing directors/ head of nursing, updated every three years.  These policies include but not limited to the following
Department nurse leaders ensure that the policies are available and current (updated within 3 years and approved by nursing director), and accessible to all nursing unit.
All nurses are aware and oriented about the above listed policies.
The nursing department performs essential monitoring to assess compliance to the nursing policies.

description: The nursing department maintains effective communication process among all levels of nursing.

subStandards.description: Nursing department has clear process directing nursing team on channels of communication among all levels. These guidelines are in alignments with the hospital communication processes.
There is a regular nursing leaders/management meeting with meeting minutes.
There is evidence of regular nursing department meetings, and it is reflected in the meeting minutes. The meeting minutes are shared with all nursing staff.
The nursing team has a system to monitor and review the implementation of effective communication. This could be done through staff feedback, satisfaction survey etc.

description: The nursing department has updated Staff work schedule (roster) system.

subStandards.description: There is a detailed nursing scheduling policy that covers including
All nursing units have work schedule updated as per the institution policy, displayed to all unit staff
There is a proper skill mix staffing for each shift as per unit needs.
The nursing department leaders conduct regular audit to monitor the compliance to the policy.
The nursing department has clear written policy to guide the nursing care plan process.
There is comprehensive nursing assessment conducted for each patient upon admission, which identifies nursing care needs for each patient using standardized assessments tools, includes:
There is an individualized documented nursing care plan developed for each patient according to nursing assessment, which is consistent with the medical plan.
Patients with specific needs (elderly, bedridden, handicapped, etc.) are assessed for level of activity/ dependency.
Patient fundamental of care needs is planned, and provided according to their needs.  E.g., feeding, drinking, mobilization, pain, skincare, hygiene.
The nursing staff perform reassessment and review the nursing care plan every shift, or upon any changes in patients’ condition and change in treatment.
The nursing assessment and plan of care is documented in patients’ medical file.
There is a regular monitoring process to ensure patients’ care plans are implemented and documented as per the policy.

description: The hospital implements a process for effective identification, and management of patients who are at falling risk (CSS).

subStandards.description: The hospital has a clear policy for effective identification, assessment, and management of  patient at risk of fall, and management of patients after fall incidence.
All concerned staff are oriented on the fall prevention policy and the assessment tool .
Hospital leaders ensure that resources are available for implementation of fall prevention policy.

Nursing team follow fall risk assessment for all patients at the point of access to determine their risk for falling across the hospital premises, when patient move from one unit to another, when patients’ condition changes, using validated fall risk assessment tool .
Interventions for fall prevention are implemented based on assessment score.
Patient assessment and interventions, patient and family teaching are documented on patient electronic record and communicated among nursing team and other healthcare providers.
Departments’ heads conduct regular audits to assess compliance to the fall prevention policy and related scales.

description: The hospital implements a process for effective identification and management of patients who are at risk for pressure ulcers (CSS).

subStandards.description: The hospital has written policies and procedures to guide proper identification, assessment, and management of patients at risk develop a pressure ulcer.
Patient assessment and interventions, patient and family teaching are documented on patient electronic record and communicated among nursing team and other healthcare providers.
The is regular audit to assess compliance with the pressure ulcer prevention and management policy and related scales.

description: Nursing team implements and maintains a standrdized nursing documentation process for every patient.

description: Rehabilitation service is provided by multidisciplinary team.

subStandards.description: There is a clear referral guide for providing medical rehabilitation services for patients within the hospital units.

Medical Rehabilitation Services is offered only after referral by a physician. The referral is requested to the specialty required i.e., physiotherapy, occupational therapy, speech and language therapy and prosthetic and orthotic.
The response to routine referrals issued within maximum 24 hours.
Rehabilitation professionals communicate effectively with the multidisciplinary team about patient’s plan of care and perform the necessary activities.
All communication and patient ‘plan of care provided are clearly documented by the rehabilitation staff and all other team members in the patient's medical record.

The plan of patient care includes a multidisciplinary team involved in the rehabilitation, and the intensity and duration of the sessions to be arranged depending on the patient’s progression and needs.
The patient’s response to therapy is documented in patient’s electronic record.

description: Patients are assessed comprehensively by medical rehabilitation professionals to identify their functional risks and needs.

subStandards.description: Patient rehabilitation care is guided by a comprehensive functional assessment process that is performed by a qualified therapist for each patient. The assessment includes collecting subjective and objective data.
Evidence based clinical assessment tools are used to generate rehabilitation goals and action plans.

Functional assessment is completed within twenty-four hours of referral. This can be applied in inpatient settings. For outpatients, it is limited by appointment date after referral which mostly exceeds 24 hours.
Functional screening and assessment findings are documented in the patient’s medical record.
The rehabilitation staff in collaboration with other multidisciplinary team develop appropriate plan of care for patients with functional needs that meets the needs of the patient.

description: The hospital has a standardized nutritional screening for all age group patients

The nutritional screening and assessment findings are documented in the patient’s medical record.

description: Hospital   maintains dry food store temperature under 25 degrees Celsius in catering facilities.

subStandards.description: Essential points (temperature and humidity) within the dry store of the catering facility, to be monitored.
Records to ensure that dry stores should be dry and cool to prevent spoilage and the swelling of canned goods. The ideal temperature range is 10°C to 15°C (50°F to 59°F) and not to exceed 25C (77F).
Records to ensure cleanness from biological, chemical and physical spoilage.
All procedures (e.g., building specifications etc.) required to ensure safety from biological, chemical, physical and allergic hazards.
